sen.j: 歌垣（うたがき）とは、特定の日時に若い男女が集まり、相互に求愛の歌謡を掛け合う呪的信仰に立つ習俗。
sen.e: "Utagaki" is a kind of folkways based on a magical belief, where young men and women gather on a specific time and date to exchange courtship songs and ballads.
"Utagaki" is a kind of folkway based on a magical belief, where young men and women gather on a specific time and date to exchange courtship songs and ballads.
"Utagaki" is a kind of folkway based on a magical belief, where young men and women gather on a specific time and date to exchange courtship songs and ballads.

sen.j: 現代では主に中国南部からインドシナ半島北部の山岳地帯に分布している。
sen.e: At present, it is practiced mainly in the mountainous area in southern China and northern Indochina.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At present, it is practiced mainly in the mountainous area in southern China and northern Indochina.
At present, it is practiced mainly in the mountainous area in southern China and northern Indochina.

sen.j: ほかに、フィリピンやインドネシアなどでも類似の風習が見られる。
sen.e: Similar customs can be seen in the Philippines and Indonesia, as well..
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Similar customs can be seen in the Philippines and Indonesia, as well..
Similar customs can be seen in the Philippines and Indonesia, as well..

sen.j: 古代日本の常陸筑波山などおいて、歌垣の風習が存在したことが『万葉集』などによりうかがうことができる。
sen.e: In ancient times, there existed a custom of utagaki in Mt. Tsukuba area in Hitachi Province and other places in Japan, as is learned from the "Manyoshu" (the "Anthology of Ten Thousand Leaves")
In ancient times, there existed a custom of utagaki in the Mt. Tsukuba area in Hitachi Province and other places in Japan, as is learned from the "Manyoshu" (the "Anthology of Ten Thousand Leaves")
In ancient times, there existed a custom of utagaki in the Mt. Tsukuba area in Hitachi Province and other places in Japan, as is learned from the "Manyoshu" (the "Anthology of Ten Thousand Leaves")

sen.j: 現代の中国南部および東南アジア北部で見られる歌垣を概観すると、祝祭日（多くの場合、播種前の春先）の夜に10代半ばから20代の男女が集会し、互いに求愛歌を掛け合いながら、対になり恋愛関係になる、といった類型が多い。
sen.e: To give an overview of utagaki practiced in the current southern China and northern South-East Asia, the custom is most typically observed in the manner that men and women in their 10s and 20s gather together in the evening of a holiday (in many cases, at the beginning of spring) and exchange love songs so that couples may get into relationship with each other.

To give an overview of utagaki currently practiced in southern China and northern South-East Asia, the custom is most typically observed in the manner that men and women in their teens and 20s gather together in the evening of a holiday (in many cases, at the beginning of spring) and exchange love songs so that couples may enter relationships with each other.

To give an overview of utagaki currently practiced in southern China and northern South-East Asia, the custom is most typically observed in the manner that men and women in their teens and 20s gather together in the evening of a holiday (in many cases, at the beginning of spring) and exchange love songs so that couples may enter relationships with each other.

sen.j: このように、歌垣は未婚男女の求婚の場という性格が強い。
sen.e: In this way, the utagaki custom has a strong tendency toward courtships among unmarried men and women.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In this way, the utagaki custom has a strong tendency toward courtships among unmarried men and women.
In this way, the utagaki custom has a strong tendency toward courtships among unmarried men and women.

sen.j: また、集団での成年式に起源すると考えられている。
sen.e: It is also considered to have originated from an initiation ceremony in a group setting.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It is also considered to have originated from an initiation ceremony in a group setting.
It is also considered to have originated from an initiation ceremony in a group setting.

sen.j: 歌垣での歌謡は、多くの場合、固定的な旋律と定型的な歌詞を持ち、三・五・七などの音数律に従う。
sen.e: Songs and ballads exchanged in an utagaki gathering are, in many cases, with fixed melodies and stylized lyrics, following a syllabic meter of three, five or seven syllables per line.
Songs and ballads exchanged in an utagaki gathering are, in many cases, with fixed melodies and stylized lyrics, following a syllabic meter of three, five, or seven syllables per line.
Songs and ballads exchanged in an utagaki gathering are, in many cases, with fixed melodies and stylized lyrics, following a syllabic meter of three, five, or seven syllables per line.

sen.j: 歌い手は、これらの約束事を守りながら即興でうたう技量と教養を必要とし、なおかつ相手の気を惹かなければならない。
sen.e: Singers of those songs and ballads are required to have a good skill and education enough to improvise any song in line with said rules, as well they have to attract the attention of their partners.

Singers of those songs and ballads are required to have sufficiently good skill and education to improvise any song in line with said rules, and as well they have to attract the attention of their partners.

Singers of those songs and ballads are required to have sufficiently good skill and education to improvise any song in line with said rules, and as well they have to attract the attention of their partners.

sen.j: 歌謡の内容は求愛歌だけにとどまらず、創世神話歌、収穫歌、豊作労働歌、葬送歌などがある。
sen.e: Contents of the songs and ballads are not limited to courtships but also include creation myths, harvests, work for ample crops, funerals and so on.
Contents of the songs and ballads are not limited to courtships but also include creation myths, harvests, work for ample crops, funerals, and so on.
Contents of the songs and ballads are not limited to courtships but also include creation myths, harvests, work for ample crops, funerals, and so on.

sen.j: 歌垣の習俗は、焼畑農業民にも稲作民にも見られるが、特に山岳焼畑地帯で顕著である。
sen.e: Though the custom of utagaki may be observed in both swidden and rice-growing farmers, it is prominent among the people in mountainous areas of slash-and-burn agriculture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although the custom of utagaki may be observed in both swidden and rice-growing farmers, it is prominent among the people in mountainous areas of slash-and-burn agriculture.
Although the custom of utagaki may be observed in both swidden and rice-growing farmers, it is prominent among the people in mountainous areas of slash-and-burn agriculture.

sen.j: もとは山岳地帯の焼畑耕作民の文化だったと考えられている。
sen.e: From this fact, utagaki is believed to have originally been a culture of farmers of swidden agriculture in mountainous terrains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From this fact, utagaki is believed to have originally been a culture of farmers of swidden agriculture in mountainous terrains.
From this fact, utagaki is believed to have originally been a culture of farmers of swidden agriculture in mountainous terrains.

sen.j: 古代日本における歌垣は、特定の日時と場所に老若男女が集会し、共同飲食しながら歌を掛け合う呪的信仰に立つ行事であり、互いに求愛歌を掛け合いながら、対になり恋愛関係になるとされる。
sen.e: In ancient Japan, the custom of utagaki was practiced as an event based on a magical belief of the people, irrespective of age and sex, who gathered on a fixed time and day at a specific place to exchange courtship songs while eating and drinking together in order to form couples who may eventually fall into love.

In ancient Japan, the custom of utagaki was practiced as an event based on a magical belief of the people, irrespective of age and sex, who gathered on a fixed time and day at a specific place to exchange courtship songs while eating and drinking together in order to form couples who may eventually fall in love.

In ancient Japan, the custom of utagaki was practiced as an event based on a magical belief of the people, irrespective of age and sex, who gathered on a fixed time and day at a specific place to exchange courtship songs while eating and drinking together in order to form couples who may eventually fall in love.

sen.j: 語源は「歌掛き（懸き）」であると考えられている。
sen.e: This "utagaki" is written in kanji charactor as "歌垣," the origin of which is believed to be another "utagaki" written in different kanji as "歌掛き(懸き)" ("calling each other by songs.")
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This "utagaki" is written in kanji characters as "歌垣," the origin of which is believed to be another "utagaki" written in different kanji as "歌掛き(懸き)" ("calling each other by songs.")
This 'utagaki' is written in kanji characters as '歌垣,' the origin of which is believed to be another 'utagaki' written in different kanji as '歌掛き(懸き)' ('calling each other by songs').
sen.cmt: " "を' 'に変更しました。ピリオドを括弧の外に出しました。

sen.j: また、東国方言の「かがい（嬥歌）」も「懸け合い」に由来すると考えられている。
sen.e: "Kagai" written in kanji as "嬥歌" is a dialect for "utagaki" spoken in Togoku region (eastern part of Japan, especially Kanto region,) which is also considered to have originated from "kakeai" ("calling each other in rhythmic dialogue.")
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Kagai" written in kanji as "嬥歌" is a dialect for "utagaki" spoken in the Togoku region (eastern part of Japan, especially the Kanto region,) which is also considered to have originated from "kakeai" ("calling each other in rhythmic dialogue.")

Kagai' written in kanji as '嬥歌' is a dialect for 'utagaki' spoken in the Togoku region (eastern part of Japan, especially the Kanto region,) which is also considered to have originated from 'kakeai' ('calling each other in rhythmic dialogue').
sen.cmt: " "を' 'に変更しました。ピリオドを括弧の外に出しました。

sen.j: 時期としては春秋に行われ、生産の予祝・感謝としての性格を持っていたとされる。
sen.e: Spring and autumn were purported to be good seasons for utagaki festivals which were assumed to have an aspect of preliminary celebration and gratitude for production.
Spring and autumn were purported to be good seasons for utagaki festivals, which were assumed to have an aspect of preliminary celebration and gratitude for production.
Spring and autumn were purported to be good seasons for utagaki festivals, which were assumed to have an aspect of preliminary celebration and gratitude for production.

sen.j: 場所は、山頂、海浜、川、そして市など、境界性を帯びた地が多く、常陸筑波山、同童子女松原、肥前杵島岳、摂津歌垣山、大和海石榴市、同軽市などの例がある。
sen.e: As for venues for utagaki meetings, well-bounded places were selected such as mountain tops, seashores, riversides, market places and so on; for example Mt. Tsukuba in Hitachi Province, Otome no Matsubara park in the same Province, Mt. Kishima-dake in Hizen Province, Mt. Utagaki-yama in Settsu Province, Tsubakichi (also known as Tsubaichi) market place in Yamato Province, Karuno-ichi market place in the same Province, and so on.

As for venues for utagaki meetings, well-bounded places were selected such as mountain tops, seashores, riversides, market places, and so on; for example, Mt. Tsukuba in Hitachi Province, Otome no Matsubara park in the same Province, Mt. Kishima-dake in Hizen Province, Mt. Utagaki-yama in Settsu Province, Tsubakichi (also known as Tsubaichi) marketplace in Yamato Province, Karuno-ichi marketplace in the same Province, and so on.

As for venues for utagaki meetings, well-bounded places were selected such as mountain tops, seashores, riversides, market places, and so on; for example, Mt. Tsukuba in Hitachi Province, Otome no Matsubara park in the same Province, Mt. Kishima-dake in Hizen Province, Mt. Utagaki-yama in Settsu Province, Tsubakichi (also known as Tsubaichi) marketplace in Yamato Province, Karuno-ichi marketplace in the same Province, and so on.

sen.j: 古代の言霊信仰の観点からは、ことばうたを掛け合うことにより、呪的言霊の強い側が歌い勝って相手を支配し、歌い負けた側は相手に服従したのだ、と説かれる。
sen.e: In the light of ancient belief in kotodama (soul or power of language,) it may be explained that one with magically stronger kotodama could win in a poetry contest and dominate his/her opponent while the other one who lost the contest had to submit himself/herself to the opponent.

In the light of ancient belief in kotodama (soul or power of language,) it may be explained that one with magically stronger kotodama could win in a poetry contest and dominate his/her opponent while the other one who lost the contest had to submit himself/herself to the opponent.

In the light of ancient belief in kotodama (soul or power of language), it may be explained that one with magically stronger kotodama could win in a poetry contest and dominate his/her opponent while the other one who lost the contest had to submit himself/herself to the opponent.

sen.j: 歌垣における男女間の求愛関係も、言霊の強弱を通じて決定されることとなる。
sen.e: Similarly, a relationship between a man and woman coupled in an utagaki meeting was determined by strength of each one's kotodama.
Similarly, a relationship between a man and woman coupled in an utagaki meeting was determined by the strength of each one's kotodama.
Similarly, a relationship between a man and woman coupled in an utagaki meeting was determined by the strength of each one's kotodama.

sen.j: 古代歌謡としての歌垣は、『古事記』『万葉集』『常陸国風土記』『肥前国風土記』などに見える。
sen.e: Ancient songs and ballads related to "utagaki" can be found in "Kojiki" ("The Records of Ancient Matters,") "Manyoshu" ("The Anthology of Myriad Leaves,") "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hitachi Province") and so on.

Ancient songs and ballads related to "utagaki" can be found in "Kojiki" ("The Records of Ancient Matters,") "Manyoshu" ("The Anthology of Myriad Leaves,") "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hitachi Province") and so on.

Ancient songs and ballads related to "utagaki" can be found in "Kojiki" ("The Records of Ancient Matters,") "Manyoshu" ("The Anthology of Myriad Leaves,") "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hitachi Province"), "Hizen no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hizen Province") and so on.
sen.cmt: 『肥前国風土記』の訳抜け対応をしました。

sen.j: 万葉集巻九の「〈……率(あども)ひて 未通女壮士(おとめおとこ)の 行き集(つど)ひ かがふ刊歌(かがい)に 人妻に 吾(あ)も交はらむ 吾が妻に 人も言問(ことと)へ……」は、筑波山の歌垣で高橋虫麻呂が詠んだ歌であり、当時の歌垣の様子を伺い知ることが出来る。
sen.e: In Volume nine of the Manyoshu Anthology, there was written a poem composed by TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro at an utagaki festival held in Mt. Tsukuba, which reads, "Let's go to kagai (dialect of "utagaki") where men and women gather to exchange poems, and I would interact with a married woman while my wife may be pursued by any other man・・・," from which we can see how things were going on at an utagaki gathering at that time.

In Volume nine of the Manyoshu Anthology, there was written a poem composed by TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro at an utagaki festival held in Mt. Tsukuba, which reads, "Let's go to kagai (dialect of "utagaki") where men and women gather to exchange poems, and I would interact with a married woman while my wife may be pursued by any other man・・・," from which we can see how things were going on at an utagaki gathering at that time.

In volume nine of the Manyoshu Anthology, there was a poem composed by TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro at an utagaki festival held in Mt. Tsukuba, which reads, 'Let's go to kagai (dialect of "utagaki") where men and women gather to exchange poems, and I would interact with a married woman while my wife might be pursued by any other man・・・,' from which we can see how things were going on at an utagaki gathering at that time.
sen.cmt: volumeのVを小文字に変更しました。Writtenを除去しました。Mayをmightに変更しました。"を'に変更しました。

sen.j: 時代が下るにつれて、呪的信仰・予祝・感謝行事としての性格は薄れ、未婚者による求婚行事となっていった。
sen.e: As time advanced, aspects of utagaki fest as a meeting for magical belief, preliminary celebration and gratitude for production became weaker than ever and gradually formed its characteristics as an event for courtship among unmarried persons.

As time advanced, aspects of utagaki fest as a meeting for magical belief, preliminary celebration, and gratitude for production became weaker than ever and gradually formed its characteristics as an event for courtship among unmarried persons.

As time advanced, aspects of utagaki fest as a meeting for magical belief, preliminary celebration, and gratitude for production became weaker than ever and gradually formed its characteristics as an event for courtship among unmarried persons.

sen.j: 特に都市の市ではその傾向を強めた。
sen.e: Especially at urban markets, this tendency became stronger.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Especially at urban markets, this tendency became stronger.
Especially at urban markets, this tendency became stronger.

sen.j: 、『古事記』には顕宗天皇と平群鮪とが女をめぐり海石榴市で歌をたたかわせた逸話が残っている。
sen.e: For example, in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters,) an anectode of Emperor Kenzo and HEGURI no Shibi was described who had fought for love of a woman by exchange of poems at Tsubakichi (or Tsubaichi) market.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), there is described an anecdote of Emperor Kenzo and HEGURI no Shibi who had fought for the love of a woman by exchange of poems at Tsubakichi (or Tsubaichi) market.

For example, in "Kojiki" ("The Records of Ancient Matters"), there is described an anecdote of Emperor Kenzo and HEGURI no Shibi who had fought for the love of a woman by exchange of poems at Tsubakichi (or Tsubaichi) market.

sen.j: 奈良時代に入ると、中国（唐）から伝来した踏歌と合流し、宮廷芸能の一つとなった。
sen.e: In the Nara Period, utagaki was merged with toka (singing and dancing) imported from China, and became one of performance arts for court.
In the Nara Period, utagaki was merged with toka (singing and dancing) imported from China, and became one of performance arts for court.
In the Nara Period, utagaki was merged with toka (singing and dancing) imported from China, and became one of performance arts for court.

sen.j: 天平6年(734年)2月には平城京朱雀門で、宝亀元年(770年)3月には河内由義宮で歌垣が開催され、それぞれ貴族・帰化氏族が二百数十名参加する大規模なショーであった。
sen.e: Utagaki festivals were held in large scales in February, 734, at Suzaku-mon Gate in then capital city Heijo and in March, 770, at Kawachi-Yugeno-miya Palace, each of which was attended by two hundreds and several tens of nobles and naturalized clans.

Utagaki festivals were held in large scale in February, 734, at Suzaku-mon Gate in the then capital city Heijo and in March, 770, at Kawachi-Yugeno-miya Palace, each of which was attended by two hundred and several tens of nobles and naturalized clans.

Utagaki festivals were held in large scale in March, 734, at Suzaku-mon Gate in the then capital city Heijo and in April, 770, at Kawachi-Yugeno-miya Palace, each of which was attended by two hundred and several tens of nobles and naturalized clans.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 歌垣はその後の歌合、連歌に影響を及ぼしたとされている。
sen.e: Utagaki is said to have influenced on subsequent uta-awase (poetry contests,) renga (linked verses) and so on.
Utagaki is said to have influenced subsequent uta-awase (poetry contests), renga (linked verses), and so on.
Utagaki is said to have influenced subsequent uta-awase (poetry contests), renga (linked verses), and so on.

sen.j: 現代にも歌垣の残存は見られ、沖縄の毛遊び（もうあしび）に歌垣の要素が強く認められるほか、福島県会津地方のウタゲイや秋田県仙北地方の掛唄にも歌垣の遺風が見られる。
sen.e: Today, traces of utagaki can be seen in such customs as Moasibi in Okinawa, Utagei in Aizu region, Fukushima Prefecture, and Kakeuta in Senboku region, Akita Prefecture.
Today, traces of utagaki can be seen in such customs as Moasibi in Okinawa, Utagei in the Aizu region, Fukushima Prefecture, and Kakeuta in the Senboku region, Akita Prefecture.
Today, traces of utagaki can be seen in such customs as Moashibi in Okinawa, Utagei in the Aizu region, Fukushima Prefecture, and Kakeuta in the Senboku region, Akita Prefecture.

sen.j: 歌垣と同様の風習は、中国南部からインドシナ半島、フィリピンやインドネシアにも存在する。
sen.e: Customs similar to utagaki are now observed in southern part of China, Indochina, the Philipines, and Indonesia.
Customs similar to utagaki are now observed in the southern part of China, Indochina, the Philipines, and Indonesia.
Customs similar to utagaki are now observed in the southern part of China, Indochina, the Philippines, and Indonesia.

sen.j: このことから、古代日本の文化は、東南アジアから中国南部にかけての地域と、一体の文化圏を築いていたという見方もある（照葉樹林文化論など）。
sen.e: From this fact, the ancient Japan is considered to have formed an integral cultural sphere including southeastern Asia and southern China, which viewpoint is claimed now by "Shoyojurin-bunkaron" (a theory of cultural sphere marked by laurel forests) and others.

From this fact, ancient Japan is considered to have formed an integral cultural sphere including southeastern Asia and southern China, which viewpoint is claimed now by "Shoyojurin-bunkaron" (a theory of cultural sphere marked by laurel forests) and others.
